content.description: As you arrive at Scorched earth, the trail hits the wall right in front of a pillar that has two routes on it. This route is the obvious aesthetic finger crack on the right. Easy ledges for the first 20 feet. Good fingers lead to tips with some really small face holds. After the blank face it eases up but there aren't many places for gear. Perhaps easier to just run it out to the chains if you have enough balls.
content.protection: .75 camalot down low. many options here. Narrows to .3 and red and yellow C3s at the crux. bring your small pieces.

content.description: The route is somewhat like its name.  A bit ugly.  Crux is about 3/4 of the way up, when you pull to the right around a roof.  Top is not hard, but is fairly crimpy.
content.protection: Just draws, but bring about 14-15 of them up with you.
content.location: When the trail forks just below the cliff, take the left fork.  This is the third obvious climb you will come to (just left of Feeding the Rat).

content.description: Start left of the first bolt and work up and right into small crimps and powerful side-pulls (crux?) that give way to a good horizontal. A rest after the third bolt gives way to fun positive edges.  Moving up and right through the roof may be the redpoint crux.
A short pleasant climb with excelent movement throughtout, a great warm up for the area.  The crux is at 3/4 height, wish it was 100'.  One of my favorite climbs in the Bozeman area.
content.location: As you head up the Scorched Earth trail, the trail forks at the top. The left fork takes you straight to Feeding the Rat. Just right of that, on a nice flat belay stance, is Pretty Polly

content.description:
Start off easy and move through non-perfect rock with big pinches. Some moves will feel lengthy. A steep slab surprises with good small holds. Then, move past some big holes and higher to the anchors.

Watch out,

birds may be nesting in the big holes.
content.location: To the right of Fistful of Steel.

content.description: This climb starts out in a straightforward manner, before getting steeper and more tricky.  Chains are about 10 feet right of Dirty Harry.  Fun but frustrating moves.
content.location: This is the second route from the far left of the cliff.  Traverse past everything to the end, and then backtrack one boltline.

content.description: As you arrive at Scorched earth, the trail hits the wall right in front of a pillar that has two routes on it. This route is the bolted line on the left. Climb easy ledges to the first bolt then onto a blank looking face. use a good finger crack to get to a small ramp underneath a roof. There are some tricky moves to get up on there, then traverse right under the roof to an old anchor. You can lower here, but there is about 15 more feet of fun climbing to another set of chains. The Climbs of SW Montana puts this at 11d which is a stretch. I'd give it 11a, and most people like to downgrade it even more. A great solid route.
content.location: Scorched Earth, right where the trail hits the crag.

content.description:
In terms of the moves, one of the best Gallatin limestone routes.

Starts off steep along the left (north) side of a little buttress, before moving into the crux after bolt 4.

The crux is kind of extended requiring some body tension.

The last moves to the anchors are technically easier, in a faint dihedral.
Starts out with a nice crack/shelf system before feeding into a one-move-wonder crux at the bulge.  Many a lead fall has been taken here, but it's worth the swing.
content.location: This is the fifth boltline you will come to after branching left on the trail right at the base of the cliff.  Just to the left of the very prominent, slippery crack of The Bad.

content.description: Crux is at the chains, with a terrible, right-reaching clip move on hard holds.  The rest of the route is alright, moving though jugs to a right-trending seam that isn't as good as it looks.
content.location: This is the third climb from the left of the wall (to the right of Dirty Harry and Nightmare before Christmas

content.description: Sustained, with 2 particularly difficult sections. A lot of the moves get a lot better once you figure out the technique. First 3 or 4 bolts are easy, then you set off into the overhang with only moderate rests until the anchors. Great fun, but a tricky if safe lead for the grade due to the overhang.
content.location: If you go the far left side of Scorched Earth, this is the 4th from last route. It's 3 routes right of Dirty Harry (5.10b) and just right of a short route, not sure of the name.

content.description:
Average Size Person's Perspective: A fine route on limestone pods and shelves. The crux for most is the right step and clip after the lower angle section but it differs for other people.  The route starts steep then mellows into easy climbing before moving right through a slight bulge (and great hand jam) to the rap rings,  rings can be tricky to clip.

Little Person's Perspective: Great route, with a pumpy start that transitions into great crimps up a column.  The obvious crux is at the sloppy vertical hand jams just below the chains, which necessitate an awkward, scary reach.
content.location: The Scorched Earth trail heads up then forks just before the wall.  Take the left fork and it will be the first climb you encounter at the wall, to the right of a tree/bush.  There is one obvious belay station to the right, which serves Pretty Polly.

content.description:
The farthest left line at the

Scorched Earth

, this perplexing route is a good lesson in funk. A fairly easy start leads to a baffling and just plain odd crux. Despite it's off-balance movement and wealth of insecurity, this climb still remains popular.  If you hop on this climb first, a majority of the routes after this will feel pretty straight forward.
content.location: Follow the trail from the parking lot to the base of the main wall, head left and up a small hill into a nook. This will be the last route on your left.

content.description: Steep climbing up an excellent slab of rock. A good, solid route with a high crux and a sweet ending. Well bolted.
content.location: This route is on the left side of a break in the wall, and just below an obvious large roof.

content.description: Wholly slick start! Difficult for the grade, this almost becomes a ten after the crux...which is the start. Quite the fight, this "warm-up" is still worth the tick. Enjoy pockets and edges up a steep face with some difficult to read sections. This was the first and is probably most climbed line in the area.
content.location: On the left-side of the Scorched Earth area, this is one of the 1st routes you'll come to after the approach. It has obvious polished feet.
